author: sky.cactus
content: IMO 4488 should not be considered without a very strong commitment to something like 4444.  If it is, then I don't consider this kicking the can down the road anymore since arguably the hardest part of 4444 is the PR/political aspect of it, and if we can solve *that* portion prior to 4488 then I feel like we have *functionally* stopped the can kicking.

author: 0xraino
content: I think this might even be overstating the political difficulty of 4444. PoS already relies on WS with similar trust infra 4444 would require.

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't a problem with weak subjectivity.  It is an issue with data availability.

author: sky.cactus
content: We are dropping the network's internal guarantee of historic data availability.

author: 0xraino
content: But arguably, if you're relying on WS to even find the correct chain, you should be comfortable with a similar trust assumption to get access to history.

author: sky.cactus
content: Finding a source in your trust network to give you a 32-byte number is *way* easier than finding a source in your trust network to give you 300GB of data.

author: 0xraino
content: Ok, maybe I'm missing something super obvious. Why can't you just find a checksum to trust and get the 300gb anywhere? (modulo griefing)

author: sky.cactus
content: We are removing the guarantee that *anywhere* will have those 300GB.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right now the gossip protocol asserts "this giant P2P network will save those 300GB replicated across all nodes".  4444 will change that to be "we guarantee that the proof of history is available, but it is up to you to find that 300GB of data elsewhere, and hope it is replicated enough that it can't disappear off the internet one day".

author: vorot93
content: Before the merge occurs, beacon chain is a glorified testnet for all intents and purposes

author: vorot93
content: So whatever guarantees it has today, applying them to execution layer is a separate political matter

author: timbeiko
content: I disagree with that last part, <@!329594653097721856>: the beacon chain has 37B$ securing it today, which is far more than the PoW "cost" securing the current chain. I think it's a bit disingenuous to claim that applying its guarantees to the current chain is a "political matter" when every team is already implementing it, the community unanimously supports this and it has been part of the Ethereum roadmap for >5 years.

author: timbeiko
content: To cause a finalized block to revert, you'd have to be willing to burn _at least_ 12B$, whereas a 51% attack on Ethereum right now seems to cost in the single digit millions per hour, as per: https://www.crypto51.app/

author: vorot93
content: Everything you wrote is correct, but misses the point. Beacon chain secures nothing that cannot be written into irregular state transition should a fuckup occur. Validator ETH only exists on paper since it‚Äôs pretty useless on its own anyway. By contrast, execution layer has all the dapps, ecosystem and network effects. Any major change in chain properties will affect all of these instantly.

author: vorot93
content: I am not saying that 4444 should not go in, I disagree with the specific line of reasoning why we should brush off potential political fallout

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, this is agree with. We definitely need to offer some viable solutions _before_ 4444 goes in and not just tell applications "sorry, history is gone, fine a backup" üëç
